Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Toxicology, Capital Medical University Beijing 100069 China 1 The two authors contributed to this work equally. Editor: Dr. S. Nan Large amounts of epidemiological evidence have confirmed the atmospheric particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure was positively correlated with the morbidity and mortality of respiratory diseases. Nevertheless, its pathogenesis remains incompletely understood, probably resulting from the activation of oxidative stress, inflammation, altered genetic and epigenetic modifications in the lung upon PM2.5 exposure. Currently, biomarker investigations have been widely used in epidemiological and toxicological studies, which may help in understanding the biologic mechanisms underlying PM2.5-elicited adverse health outcomes. Here, the emerging biomarkers to indicate PM2.5-respiratory system interactions were summarized, primarily related to oxidative stress (ROS, MDA, GSH, etc.), inflammation (Interleukins, FENO, CC16, etc.), DNA damage (8-OHdG, γH2AX, OGG1) and also epigenetic modulation (DNA methylation, histone modification, microRNAs). The identified biomarkers shed light on PM2.5-elicited inflammation, fibrogenesis and carcinogenesis, thus may favor more precise interventions in public health. It is worth noting that some inconsistent findings may possibly relate to the inter-study differentials in the airborne PM2.5 sample, exposure mode and targeted subjects, as well as methodological issues. Further research, particularly by -omics technique to identify novel, specific biomarkers, is warranted to illuminate the causal relationship between PM2.5 pollution and deleterious lung outcomes. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Particulate matter Oxidative stress Inflammation Epigenetics Pulmonary function Biomarker 1 Introduction Ambient particulate matter (PM) pollution has been widely regarded as an important environmental risk factor, contributing to tremendous disease burden, health and economic loss. According to the report of State of global air/2020 released by the Health Effects Institute, air pollution is the 4th leading risk factor for early death worldwide in 2019 (Health Effects Institute, 2020). Among these, ambient PM2.5 pollution accounts for 62% of all air pollution-attributable deaths and 55% of lost disability-adjusted lifer years (DALYs), that is, 4.14 (95% uncertainty interval [UI]: 2.50–3.36) million deaths and 118 (95% UI: 95.9–138) million DALYs (Health Effects Institute, 2020). The Global Burden of Disease Study (GBD) reveals ambient PM pollution has increased from 13th in 1990–7th in 2019 leading risk factor for attributable DALYs globally (GBD 2019 Risk Factors Collaborators, 2020). PM2.5 pollution is an extremely pressing public health issue in China, and still remains a challenge. In despite of a 33.3% decline in the annual average level of PM2.5 during 2013–2017, over 80% of the Chinese population still experienced PM2.5 that exceeded the least stringent WHO air quality interim target of 35 μg/m3 (Yin et al., 2020). The global cost of health effects attributable to ambient PM2.5 pollution has increased to 3552 billion in 2013 (Niu et al., 2017). In China, the economic loss attributable to air pollution was reported to account for about 0.72%–10% of its Gross Domestic Production (GDP) based on different study settings (Chen and Bloom, 2019). A large amount of epidemiological evidence links short- and long-term PM2.5 exposures with higher rates of disease prevalence and mortality, among which respiratory diseases are most obvious (Lu et al., 2015). According to the GBD 2017, 35% of deaths due to lower respiratory infections in China were associated with air pollution (Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME), 2017). It was estimated that the per capita economic burden due to air pollution-attributable chronic respiratory diseases in China amount to a loss of US$ 222 and US$ 89 in 1990–2030 and 2015–2030, respectively (Chen and Bloom, 2019). In an epidemiological study conducted in 272 cities in China, a 10 μg/m3 increase of atmospheric PM2.5 would contribute to 0.29% (95% posterior interval [PI], 0.17%−0.42%) increment in mortality from respiratory diseases (Chen et al., 2017). PM2.5 exposure was pointed out to impair lung function (Guo et al., 2018, 2019), and related to the occurrence and aggravate of bronchial asthma (Fan et al., 2016). PM2.5 exposure also increases the risk and mortality of lung cancer (Li et al., 2017a). In 2013, PM from outdoor air pollution has been defined as a Group 1 human carcinogen (Loomis et al., 2013). Accumulating experimental evidence have demonstrated PM2.5 can be easily inhaled into and deposit in the trachea, bronchi and even alveoli, resulting in adverse effects on respiratory system and function. A recent in vivo study found that PM2.5 exposure would increase lung susceptibility, in despite of a gradual recovery from lung injury after the cessation of PM2.5 exposure (Ren et al., 2020). Overall, PM2.5 acts as a possible etiological factor of lung diseases (Xing et al., 2016), but its pathogenesis is far from fully understood. Additionally, the complexity of chemical composition in PM2.5 brings in a great challenge to toxicological evaluation. A biomarker is kind of a biological observation result, which can be a cell or a small molecular mediator, and is an index used to detect pathophysiological processes or reactions after exposure (Califf, 2018). Biomarkers could be exposure or effect indicators, which were intensively applied to explore the inter-connection between the environment stimuli and adverse health events (Rylance et al., 2013). In recent years, biomarkers have been used as a powerful tool to investigate the interplay of PM2.5 with its-associated health outcomes. Overall, the adverse respiratory effects of PM2.5 were mainly in the following aspects: oxidative stress, inflammation, respiratory epithelial injury, fibrosis, genetic and epigenetic changes. Here, this paper mainly reviews the current progress in biomarkers investigation related to respiratory toxicity upon PM2.5 exposure, which would facilitate to understand the contribution of PM2.5 on the etiology, disease development of respiratory diseases. 2 Biomarkers implicated following PM2.5 exposure 2.1 Oxidative stress Oxidative stress was commonly regarded as a major way of respiratory injury caused by PM2.5. It has been well-documented that respiratory deposition PM2.5 could cause reactive oxygen species (ROS) in lung due to redox reaction of its components with lung antioxidants, resulting in the activation of pulmonary and/or systemic oxidative stress (Guan et al., 2019; Marchini et al., 2020; Guo et al., 2021). In turn, data from population study (Qiu et al., 2021) and animal models (Yang et al., 2018b) suggested that the upregulation of antioxidant system was beneficial to counteract PM2.5-induced lung injury. 2.1.1 ROS The excessive generation of ROS (e.g., superoxide, hydroxyl radical and hydrogen peroxide [H2O2]) stimulated by the external air pollutants was commonly used as the most direct evidence of oxidative stress. Increased H2O2 content in exhaled breath condensate (EBC) was found in secondhand smoke-exposed healthy people (Kostikas et al., 2013). An in vivo study conducted by Gurgueira et al. demonstrated a rapid ROS generation in the lungs of rats after PM2.5 inhalation (Gurgueira et al., 2002). Similarly, a significantly elevated ROS level was detected in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) of PM2.5-exposed mice (Jin et al., 2017), and also the in vitro lung/bronchial epithelial cells, BEAS-2B (Liu et al., 2020). Yang et al. reported PM2.5 elevated ROS levels in BEAS-2B, whereas no alteration on the enzymatic activity of antioxidant SOD and total antioxidant capacity was detected (Yang et al., 2016). Their further component analysis revealed that the increased ROS level was associated with Fe in PM2.5. Another domestic study revealed summer-winter differences in PM2.5-induced respiratory toxicity, owing to a severer induction of ROS generation and GSH depletion by winter PM2.5, as well as inflammatory response (Chen et al., 2018b). The heterogeneity of PM2.5-induced oxidative potential was closely linked with its composition. Studies have reported the greater induction of respiratory toxicity by organic fraction of PM2.5 over water-soluble PM2.5 (Meng and Zhang, 2007; Song et al., 2019). Verma et al. identified organic aerosol as the main ROS-related sources of water-soluble PM2.5 fractions (Verma et al., 2015). Gali et al. harvested solid particulate phase (solid-PM) and semi-volatile PM (SV-PM) by using front and backup filters (Gali et al., 2017). They concluded SV-PM triggered more than two-fold ROS production compared to solid-PM on a PM2.5 mass basis (Gali et al., 2019). Simultaneously, organic extract from solid-PM and SV-PM was found capable of inducing a much higher oxidative stress in macrophages and epithelial cells compared to water-soluble PM2.5 extract (Gali et al., 2019). Also, hydrophobic components in both water-soluble and insoluble organic aerosols were pointed out to be a major contributor to the environmental PM-related oxidative properties (Verma et al., 2012). An in vitro evidence revealed water-soluble fraction of PM2.5 triggered ROS production at early response times (2, 4, and 6 h), and conversely, water-insoluble fraction increased ROS just at a later time (24 or 48 h) (Zou et al., 2016). Researches have shown polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) was the major redox-active component on PM2.5, and its content was directly correlated with ROS generation capacity (Sklorz et al., 2007; Sun et al., 2018). An in vitro study performed by Jin et al. quantified metals and PAHs accounting for 38% and 24% on PM2.5-elicited ROS generation in Beijing and Guangzhou, respectively (Jin et al., 2019). In comparison to summer PM2.5, higher accumulations of some transition metals such as Cu, Mn and Co in winter PM2.5 samples may explain the seasonal variation of ROS generated by PM2.5 (Chen et al., 2018b). 2.1.2 Malondialdehyde (MDA) MDA in urine, serum or EBC was frequently monitored to reflect air pollution-derived systemic or airway oxidative stress. Quite a few studies have proven the elevated MDA level in accordance with high PM2.5 exposure. For instance, per inter-quartile range (IQR) increase in airborne PM2.5 was related to a 10%−20% increase in urinary MDA level (Gong et al., 2014). He et al. also demonstrated the correlation of an IQR increase in 12 h PM2.5 with 6.1% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.6%−10.8%) increase in urinary MDA (He et al., 2020). Moreover, a pilot study of nine volunteers traveled from Germany to China observed strong correlations between PM2.5 and urinary MDA (Wu et al., 2017b). A decline of EBC MDA in healthy young adults was observed to associate with air quality improvement during the Beijing Olympic Games period (Gong et al., 2013). A panel study of 125 Beijing residents to compare the association of PM2.5 with biomarkers reflecting respiratory events observed significant associations of EBC MDA with PM2.5 at lag 3, 4, and 5 (Gong et al., 2014). Another panel study investigated 97 elderly residents in metropolitan area of Los Angeles, and showed an interquartile increase in PAHs (5-d average) was related to a 6.3% (95% CI: 1.1%−11.6%) increment in EBC MDA (Zhang et al., 2016). By meta-analysis, Li et al. showed a 1.60% (95% CI: 0.21%, 3.01%) increase in MDA (P = 0.024) accompanying with per 10 μg/m3 increase of short-term PM2.5 exposure (Li et al., 2020). Consistently, in vivo and in vitro data confirmed the elevation of MDA in the lung tissues of PM2.5-exposed animal models (Li et al., 2018b; Lin et al., 2009) and bronchial epithelial cells (Cachon et al., 2014; Wu et al., 2017a). 2.1.3 Antioxidants Some in vivo and in vitro studies have confirmed that the declined glutathione (GSH), whilst increased oxidized glutathione (GSSG) in lung tissue or cells after PM2.5 exposure (Chen et al., 2018b; Riva et al., 2011; Zhu et al., 2019). Oppositely, an enhanced GSH content was detected in BALF of healthy volunteers after wood smoke exposure (Sehlstedt et al., 2010). The increased GSH in BALF may reflect GSH mobilized to the air-lung interface to cope with oxidative stress induced by the investigated wood smoke-derived PM. Besides, antioxidants, such as GSH-Px, superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) were inhibited after PM2.5 exposure in mouse lung tissues (Wang et al., 2015a). Likewise, there were exceptions to this tendency. For example, chalk PM2.5 exposure could make oxidative damages on alveolar macrophages (AMs), characterized by the increased intracellular MDA and CAT levels while decreased SOD level (Zhang et al., 2015). In addition, heme oxygenase 1 (HO-1) is an inducible antioxidant enzyme to against PM2.5-caused oxidative stress (Li et al., 2017b), as well as inflammation (Kim et al., 2020). But no alteration of HO-1 was found in the bronchi of the healthy volunteers exposed to wood smoke (Sehlstedt et al., 2010). 2.1.4 8-iso-prostaglandin-F2α (8-iso-PGF2a) 8-iso-PGF2a is proposed to be a reliable indicator to oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation (Awad et al., 1993; Montuschi et al., 2004). Upon PM2.5 exposure, the content of 8-iso-PGF2a in urine was reported to be increased, as well as 8-isoprostane in EBC (Ferguson et al., 2016). In welding workers, a 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 corresponded to the increments in 8-OHdG and 8-iso-PGF2α by 2.15% and 8.43%, respectively (Lai et al., 2016). Curiously, urinary 8-iso-PGF2a in healthy subjects exposed to wood smoke was decreased after PM exposure (Stockfelt et al., 2013). 2.1.5 EBC pH EBC pH value is a valid indicator for airway acidification (Vaughan et al., 2003), and has been proved to relate to respiratory oxidative stress and inflammation (Gessner et al., 2003). In 404 healthy volunteers, only 6.4% of EBC samples present a pH range less than 7.4 (Paget-Brown et al., 2006). Healthy people showed a decline in pH value of airway after secondhand smoke exposure (Kostikas et al., 2013). Similar findings were reported in a study of firemen exposure to wood smoke (Ferguson et al., 2016). In addition, Gong et al. reported EBC pH was significantly correlated with PM2.5 from lag 0 to lag 5 (Gong et al., 2014). 2.2 Inflammation Inflammation is a defense-based pathological response after external stimulation. Toxic components in the air, such as organic compounds and metals, can cause inflammation and damage to the respiratory system when they come into contact with the respiratory tract. The excessive inflammation is considered as a major causal event, resulting in the occurrence or aggravation of respiratory diseases. Experimental data have revealed the activation of inflammatory responses by PM2.5 in in vitro cultured human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE) (Zhou et al., 2015), lung epithelial cells (A549) (Wessels et al., 2010) and mice lungs in vivo (Riva et al., 2011). Panel studies performed by Jaafari et al. revealed PM exposure increased inflammatory biomarkers, e.g., interleukin-6 (IL-6) and white blood cells (WBC) (Jaafari et al., 2021). In particular, the changes in biomarkers varied by the source of PM exposure (Jaafari et al., 2020, 2021). Oxidative stress in high level could activate the oxidative pathways (e.g., NF-κB, MAPK) to modulate inflammation (Li et al., 2003; Guo et al., 2015, 2016). Along with higher levels of ROS and MDA, the secretions of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6 and TNF-α) were detected in PM2.5-treated BEAS-2B cells, as well as nitric oxide (NO) production (Song et al., 2019). A proteomic analysis revealed the activation of antioxidant enzymes (e.g., CAT, HO-1) in macrophage (Raw264.7) at a lower dose of organic extract of diesel exhaust particulate (DEP), whilst the induction of pro-inflammatory related enzymes required a higher dose. He et al. also revealed PM2.5-triggered inflammation in type II alveolar cell-rich lungs was predominantly oxidative stress-dependent, but not LPS/MyD88-dependent (He et al., 2017). In addition, Club Cell secretory proteins (e.g., CC16) secreted mainly by non-ciliated bronchiolar Clara cells and lung surfactant proteins (SPs) by alveolar type II epithelial cells could protect the respiratory system against inflammatory damage. For instance, CC16 could inhibit inflammatory cell infiltration (Johansson et al., 2009). In DEP-treated A549 cells, the expression of anti-inflammatory CC16 was negatively correlated with pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, −8) (Vattanasit et al., 2014). 2.2.1 Inflammatory cells Inflammatory cells gather in the inflammatory site and release inflammatory mediators to particulate the inflammatory response. Inflammatory cells were detected in sputum samples from 9 healthy volunteers exposed to PM2.5–10, among which, the number of neutrophils was increased (Alexis et al., 2006). Some studies pointed out the induction of airway hyperresponsiveness by PM2.5 was associated with neutrophils (Zhao et al., 2019c), not eosinophils (Hosseini et al., 2016). NC/Nga mice are sensitive to respiratory allergy induced by environmental chemical allergens (Nishino et al., 2014). Ogino et al. reported PM2.5 induced asthma-like airway inflammation in NC/Nga mice, where PM2.5 increased the total cell counts including eosinophils in BALF (Ogino et al., 2017). Similar results were found in PM2.5-exposed mice, that is, PM2.5 significantly increased the number of macrophages, neutrophils and lymphocytes in BALF of mice (He et al., 2015). After the phagocytosis of inhaled particles, alveolar macrophage releases chemotactic mediators that could attract inflammatory cells into the adjacent lung tissue. The pro-inflammatory mediators released by alveolar macrophages are crucial to the pathogenesis of PM2.5-caused inflammatory and allergic lung diseases (Shoenfelt et al., 2009). 2.2.2 Inflammatory mediator Cytokines were synthetized and secreted by immune or non-immune cells in response to a stimulus, thereafter regulating gene expression, immune response, inflammation and other cellular functions. Interleukins (ILs) were linked with pulmonary inflammatory processes induced by PM (Alfaro-Moreno et al., 2008). IL-1β has been detected to be elevated in children exposed to black carbon (De Prins et al., 2014), and also in taxi driver owing to traffic-related air pollution (Brucker et al., 2013). However, a study of Swedish paper workers showed the opposite (Westberg et al., 2016). An in vitro study revealed the high concentrations of PAHs and nickel (Ni) in PM2.5 samples were strongly associated with high level of IL-1β in BEAS-2B cells (Yang et al., 2016). IL-6 is known to cause pulmonary inflammation and injury in response to environmental insults to the lung (Thacker, 2006). Short- or long-term PM2.5 exposure increased IL-6 in human nasal lavage fluid (NAL) (Janssen et al., 2015) and mice BALF (Zhao et al., 2019b). Through monitoring indoor PM2.5 level and collected sputum samples from 430 healthy children, researchers figured out the association between indoor PM2.5 and IL-6 levels, and urban children had higher IL-6 levels than rural children (Nazariah et al., 2013). Also, long-term and high-level PM2.5 exposure was reported to cause a remarkable increase in circulating IL-6 in a mixed population (Hajat et al., 2015). Recently, Zhu et al. found that per 10 mg/m3 increase in PM2.5 concentration was dramatically correlated with a 4.66% increase in IL-6 level (95% CI: 1.14%−8.18%, P = 0.010) (Zhu et al., 2021). IL-8 is a chemokine that mainly acts on neutrophils, also known as neutrophil-activating protein. Populational study have reported increased IL-8 and TNFα in sputum of healthy volunteers exposed to PM2.5–10 (Alexis et al., 2006). Experimental evidence also showed the level of IL-1β, −6, −8 and TNFα were all remarkably increased in BALF of rats after pulmonary exposure to PM2.5 via intratracheal instillation (Zhao et al., 2018) and in vitro BEAS-2B (Ndong Ba et al., 2019). It is worthy to note the conflicting findings in the relationship between PM2.5 exposure and cytokines. Exposure to PM2.5 in farmers was negatively correlated to IL-4, −6, −8 and −13, as well as to TNFα and interferon-gamma (IFNγ) (Audi et al., 2017). This phenomenon was explained by adaptability owing to the long-term exposure to PM2.5. Similarly, inverse correlation of long-term air pollution exposure with inflammatory markers was observed by Forbes et al. (Forbes et al., 2009). The declined IL-1β, −6 were also detected in factory dust-exposed Swedish paper workers (Westberg et al., 2016). Toxicological studies have shown an induction of IL-6 whilst inhibition of IL-8 after exposure to PM2.5 (Alfaro-Moreno et al., 2009; Fuentes-Mattei et al., 2010). The release of IL-8 and monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) in A549 cells, as well as IL-6 and TNFα secreted from macrophages (Raw264.7), were dose-dependently increased following PM2.5 treatment (Mitkus et al., 2013). Impressively, the elements Ni, arsenic (As), and vanadium (V) were regarded as the most important metals to be closely linked with the induction or inhibition of cytokines upon PM2.5 exposure (Gioda et al., 2011). Moreover, an in vitro study performed by Rodriguez-Cotto et al. demonstrated the site-specific and time-dependent influence of PM on cytokines (Rodríguez-Cotto et al., 2014). Additionally, the pro-inflammatory potential of PM was particle size-dependent (Mantecca et al., 2010). 2.2.3 Fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FENO) FENO is currently proposed as a biomarker for detection of airway inflammation (Dinh-Xuan et al., 2015). NO in the respiratory system is mainly produced by constitutive nitric oxide synthase (NOS) and inducible NOS (iNOS). A variety of proinflammatory cytokines can induce a large number of NOS expression, resulting in a large release of NO (Ricciardolo, 2014). In vivo data showed an increased expression of iNOS in the lung tissues of mice after exposed to PM2.5 (Li et al., 2017a; Zhang et al., 2018). Air pollution was confirmed to be associated with increase in FENO in children (Delfino et al., 2006), young adult (Huang et al., 2012b) and also elderly people (Adamkiewicz et al., 2004). For instance, a study of 130 children monitored the exposure of carbon black was positively associated with FENO (De Prins et al., 2014). 2.2.4 CC16 Serum CC16 was extensively applied to evaluate the integrity and permeability of lung epithelium. Increased level of CC16 in serum was observed after acute exposure to diverse environmental pollutants exposure, including PM (Madsen et al., 2008). Wang et al. conducted a panel study among healthy, nonsmoking college students in Shanghai, China, and reported the serum CC16 level was elevated immediately at 0–2 h after PM2.5 exposure and this upward trend could last for up to 24 h (Wang et al., 2017). Apart from in blood, CC16 can also appear in urine, but with a slightly longer time lag (Timonen et al., 2004; Jacquemin et al., 2009). Timonen et al. assessed the associations between urinary CC16 level and PM exposure in patients with coronary heart disease, and found urinary CC16 level corresponding to an increase of PM2.5 levels in Helsinki, especially in patients with lung disorders (Timonen et al., 2004). On the other hand, serum CC16 level was recognized as a potential indicator to pulmonary dysfunction and obstructive pulmonary disease (Rava et al., 2013). Growing evidence have suggested the anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects of CC16 in the lungs (Broeckaert and Bernard, 2000). Wang et al. indicated an immediate impairment in lung function upon acute PM2.5 exposure by virtue of the loss of pulmonary epithelium integrity, as evidenced by increased serum CC16 (Wang et al., 2017). By contrast, prospective studies have shown that low serum concentrations of CC16 were associated with an accelerated progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD) or increased risk of lung cancer death in the general adult population (Guerra et al., 2015). Consistently, the decline in CC16 concentration was observed after environmental exposure to cigarette smoke (Van Miert et al., 2005; Zhu et al., 2015), diesel exhaust (Gowdy et al., 2008) and heave metal Cr (Zhao et al., 2014; Li et al., 2015). Researchers speculated that atmospheric pollution compromised the pulmonary permeability upon acute exposure, leading to the secretion of CC16 protein in extrapulmonary fluid (Leite et al., 2018). In turn, a consequence of decreased secretion of CC16 after long-term or chronic exposure may attribute to destruction of lung Clara cells or their differentiation for the repair of damaged lung tissue (Leite et al., 2018). In a traffic-related study of healthy, nonsmoking volunteers in Netherlands (Zuurbier et al., 2011), no consistent association between PM2.5 and serum CC16 was observed after 2-h commute during the morning rush hour. That was in line with no detectable acute effects of traffic-related PM exposure on blood-gas permeability and pulmonary function among healthy Caucasian nonsmokers (Bräuner et al., 2009). And also, Zhao et al. observed no difference of CC16 between traffic policemen and the general population, but remarkable lower in lung function, as well as higher systemic inflammatory response were noticed in traffic policemen due to PM2.5 exposure (Zhao et al., 2015). 2.2.5 Pulmonary surfactant proteins (SPs) Growing evidence indicate hydrophilic SP-A and SP-D as pulmonary host defense molecules, participate in mechanical functions of the lung, and serve as potent antioxidants to modulate oxidation of the phospholipids (Bridges et al., 2000). Specifically, they have been proposed as molecular biomarkers for diagnosis and prognostic evaluation in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) (Greene et al., 2002; Ley et al., 2014). Elevated levels of SP-A and SP-D in serum were reported in patients with IPF and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (Kuroki et al., 1993). The alterations of their levels reflect dysfunction, injury and apoptosis of type II alveolar epithelial cells (Ley et al., 2014). It was found that the levels of serum SP-D and SP-A in coking plant workers were higher than those in healthy non-smokers, meanwhile, SP-A increased slowly after long-term PM2.5 exposure, indicating a rise in pulmonary surfactant compensation for lung homeostasis (Wang et al., 2018b). However, no significant alteration of SP-D in EBC and blood was detected in firemen exposed to wood smoke (Ferguson et al., 2016). Animal experimental evidence also support PM could modulate pulmonary SPs and lung function. For instance, the expression of SP-A in PM2.5-exposed rat lungs was decreased, conversely, the cell counts of macrophages, monocytes, lymphocytes were increased in BALF (Aztatzi-Aguilar et al., 2016). Similarly, SP-A and SP-D were decreased in the lung tissue of mice following DEP exposure at a concentration of 0.5 mg/m3, but not at a higher concentration of 2 mg/m3 (Gowdy et al., 2008). The recovery in expression and production of SP-A and SP-D may due to hypertrophy of type II cells caused by prolonged exposure to air pollutants (Gowdy et al., 2008). In vitro study also demonstrated that SP-A in A549 cells was increased under DEP exposure at a lower dose (25 μg/mL), but no significant change at 50–100 μg/mL (Vattanasit et al., 2014). 2.3 DNA damage It has been well-documented the induction of DNA strand breaks caused by PM2.5 by a majority of human, animal and cell studies (Sørensen et al., 2003; Ma et al., 2015). Møller et al. indicated air pollution particles led to oxidatively damaged DNA through oxidative stress and inflammation (Møller et al., 2014). If unrepaired or repaired incorrectly, cytotoxicity, mutations or chromosomal translocations may occur. Indeed, PM2.5 exposure was reported to highly inhibit nucleotide excision repair (NER) in human lung cells, resulting in the suppressed DNA repair and promotion of DNA replication errors (Mehta et al., 2008). Meng et al. revealed the potency of DNA damage by PM2.5 from both sand storm and normal weather, and the organic compounds and insoluble particle-core acting as the main contributors (Meng and Zhang, 2007). 2.3.1 8-hydroxy-2′-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG) 8-OHdG, an oxidatively modified guanine derivative, is extensively applied to indicate oxidative stress-mediated DNA damage upon environmental stress like PM2.5 (Zanolin et al., 2015). 8-OHdG in urine commonly serves as a detectable biomarker of early effects upon PM2.5 exposure. By studying thirty-six schoolchildren during Olympic Games in Beijing, Lin et al. reported substantial reductions in air pollution, urinary 8-OHdG and MDA during the Olympic intervention period (Lin et al., 2015). They revealed the significant associations of MDA and 8-OHdG with air-borne PM2.5 and black carbon. Lee et al. found a dramatically increase in urinary 8-OHdG owing to an occupational exposure to DEP-derived PM2.5 (Lee et al., 2010). 8-OHdG in urine was also increased after exposure to traffic-related PM2.5 in vehicle (Neophytou et al., 2014). A longitudinal study revealed a 11% increase in 8-OHdG per 10 μg/m3 increase in personal PM2.5 exposure level (p = 0.007) (Huang et al., 2012a). By using a group of boilermakers who was exposed to residual oil fly ash and metal fumes in Boston, USA (Kim et al., 2004), researchers found an increase of 1.67 μg/g (95% CI, 0.21–3.14) in urinary 8-OHdG per 1 mg/m3 increase of PM2.5. Circulating lymphocytes was considered as a substitute for the assessment of PM-elicited pulmonary oxidative DNA damage. A human study recruiting 51 healthy people living in areas with heavy traffic in Bangkok, found 8-OHdG levels in lymphocyte DNA were increased and positively connected with the levels of PM2.5 and particle-bound PAHs (Vattanasit et al., 2014). Moreover, a panel study of 49 students from central Copenhagen, Denmark suggested that independent of PM2.5 mass, water-soluble transition metals (V; chromium, Cr) in PM2.5 were positively associated with 8-OHdG in lymphocytes (Sørensen et al., 2005). Likewise, animal and cell studies showed that PM exposure increased 8-OHdG in rats (Lei et al., 2005; Chen et al., 2015b) and in vitro cultured bronchial epithelial cells (Billet et al., 2018). One traffic-related PM2.5 exposure study found 8-OHdG concentration was positively correlated with PM2.5 mass, as well as PAHs and heavy metals, while not with polar organic species (Wei et al., 2009). Huang et al. revealed that PAHs bound to PM2.5 induced an increase in urinary 8-OHdG by virtue of elevating 1-hydroxypyrene-glucuronide (1-OHPG) in urine (Huang et al., 2012a). Another study in coke-even workers also found the urinary 8-OHdG linking to five heavy metals (As; Cr; Ni; Pb; cadmium, Cd), as well as PAH (Wang et al., 2015b). Furthermore, high levels of co-exposure to PAHs and heavy metals resulted in robustly oxidative DNA damage and lipid peroxidation. 2.3.2 γH2AX The phosphorylation of histone H2AX at serine 139 (named as γH2AX) is one of the earliest events after DNA damage (Rios-Doria et al., 2006), and frequently used for indicating DNA double-strand breaks. Yang et al. collected PM2.5 from six cities in China, and enhanced level of γH2AX were detected in BEAS-2B cells after PM2.5 treatment, especially that from Guangzhou, possibly due to its stronger induction of ROS (Yang et al., 2016). Further, their data showed the content of Fe and Cr in PM were significantly related to DNA damage. Similarly, another in vitro study also found that when compared to rural samples, urban PM0.3–2.5 exposure caused a higher level of γH2AX in BEAS-2B, probably attributing to the contents of inorganic chemicals, such as PAHs and Fe (Borgie et al., 2015). Besides, H2AX gene mutations were related to DNA damage repair defect (Mah et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012a). In an epidemiological study of 307 healthy urban residents, the researchers monitored PM2.5 exposure and collected blood to isolate lymphocytes (Sun et al., 2015). Finally, they found increased DNA damage along with PM2.5 exposure, as indicated by % Tail DNA using Comet assay. Meanwhile, three single nucleotide polymorphisms of H2AX corresponding to PM2.5-modulated DNA damage levels were identified, including rs10790283 G >A, rs604714 C >A and rs7759 A> G. 2.3.3 8-oxoguanine glycosylase 1 (OGG1) OGG1 is a kind of DNA glycosylase that can recognize and remove bases that are altered in the base excision to repair (BER) pathway, such as 8-OHdG, and participate in the repair of oxidative DNA damage (Sampath and Lloyd, 2019). In a study of rats, OGG1 mRNA level was up-regulated in the lungs after exposure to either PM2.5 or 9-nitroanthracene (9-NA), a typical nitro-PAHs compound in PM2.5 (Li et al., 2017b). Simultaneously, PM2.5 and 9-NA inhibited expressions of DNA damage repair genes, which may surpass the scavenging effect of OGG1 on damaged DNA. Another in vitro study found that overexpression of OGG1 could alleviate PM2.5-induced ROS, oxidative damage and apoptosis in BEAS-2B cells (Yang et al., 2015). By contrast, Yang et al. found OGG1 deficiency could aggravate PM2.5-induced lung injury and pulmonary fibrosis, which was mediated by oxidative stress and the hyperactivation of NF-κB signaling (Yang et al., 2020). 2.4 Epigenetic marker Epigenetic alterations are increasing being linked with gene dysregulation, cellular response induced by environmental pollutants like PM (De Prins et al., 2013; Ladd-Acosta and Fallin, 2015). Together with genetic events, epigenetic changes were proven to be a major contributor to diseased phenotypes after repeated exposure to atmospheric PM2.5 (Leclercq et al., 2017). 2.4.1 DNA methylation DNA methylation is closely involved in the regulation of series of cellular processes, including genomic imprinting, chromatin remodeling and chromosome stability. Current studies have demonstrated DNA methylation modifications in specific genes or non-coding repetitive elements were altered upon PM2.5 stimulus (Baccarelli et al., 2009; Salam et al., 2012). In a study of 48 healthy, non-smoking adults, total DNA methylation in whole blood was found to be inversely associated with PM2.5 (De Prins et al., 2013). Another study analyzed the DNA methylation pattern in children (aged 7–15 y) by using the Human Methylation 27 K Bead Chip with 27,578 CpG loci (Rossnerova et al., 2013). They revealed 9916 CpG sites with remarkably different methylation between children from the highly polluted area and the control region, from which 58 CpG sites had differences more than 10%. DNA methylation was associated with respiratory health. Lepeule et al. found the gene promoter hypomethylation of Carnitine O-acetyltransferase, toll-like receptor-2 (TLR2) and coagulation factor-3 linking with lower pulmonary function. Conversely, hypomethylation of IFNγ and IL-6 were related to the improvement of lung function (Lepeule et al., 2012). DNA methylation may account for PM2.5-mediated inflammatory pathways (Wang et al., 2018a). A cohort study of elder population from the Normative Aging Study revealed that methylation status related to inflammation-related genes, glucocorticoid receptor (GCR) and TLR2, contributed to lower lung function induced by PM2.5 (Lepeule et al., 2014). A nested subcohort study of African American and Dominican children showed transition metal V (PM component) exposure was associated with lower buccal cell DNA methylation of allergic and proinflammatory asthma genes, primarily IL-4, IFNγ and NOS2A (Jung et al., 2017). As a tumor suppressor gene, DLEC1 can reduce the invasion and metastasis of tumor cells (Kwong et al., 2007). The abnormal methylation of DLEC1 is associated with esophageal and lung cancers. In a study of 496 patients, PM2.5 exposure was positively correlated with DLEC1 methylation, and exercise can alleviate its hypermethylation and subsequent adverse reactions related to PM2.5 (Chou et al., 2020). The imprinted control region (ICR) of imprinted gene is more sensitive to environmental changes (Smeester et al., 2014). In a study on PM2.5 exposure of college students, DNA methylation changes in one non-imprinted gene (CYP1B1) and eight ICRs, especially L3MBTL1, were observed to be associated with PM2.5 components, in despite of no direct correlation between DNA methylation and personal PM2.5 exposure mass (Liang et al., 2021). A few epidemiology studies showed the link of alterations in DNA methylation at the NOS promoter region with PM exposure. In a cohort study of electric furnace steel plant workers, decreased iNOS methylation was detected after PM exposure (Tarantini et al., 2009). Conversely, increased iNOS methylation was reported in welders who were occupationally exposed to metal-rich PM2.5 (Kile et al., 2013). A cohort of children provided evidence that PM2.5 exposure was associated with DNA methylation of NOS genes, primarily NOS2A and NOS3 (Breton et al., 2012). Salam et al. also found the interrelated effects of short-term PM2.5 exposure, NOS2 promoter haplotypes and methylation on FENO levels in children (Salam et al., 2012). A longitudinal study among COPD patients in Shanghai, China regarded organic carbon, element carbon, NO3 - and NH4 + in PM2.5 as major contributors for declined NOS2A methylation and increased FENO (Chen et al., 2015a). Experimental data also provided preliminary evidence that DEP and PM2.5 constituents (e.g., black carbon, PAH, heavy metals) were responsible for epigenetic regulation in DNA methylation in lungs (Belinsky et al., 2002). LINE-1 has been recognized as a mediator of pulmonary diseases, especially lung cancer (Zhang et al., 2019). LINE-1 hypomethylation could induce genomic alterations and disruption of gene transcription. Human studies have revealed a decreased LINE-1 methylation after PM2.5 or black carbon exposure in the Normative Aging Study (Baccarelli et al., 2009). Animal studies of rats found short-term and prolonged exposure to traffic-derived PM2.5 significant decreased LINE-1 and iNOS methylation, whilst increased p16CDNK2A and adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) methylation in lung tissue (Ding et al., 2016a). Even exposure to PM2.5 for 4 h, a remarkable LINE-1 hypomethylation was detected in DNA from blood and lung tissues. Curiously, their data indicated a systemic regulation of methylation changes for restoration of the normal levels after the adaption to PM pollution. However, in a panel study among boilermaker welders (Kile et al., 2013), investigators found that no obvious association between occupational PM2.5 exposure and LINE-1 or Alu methylation. These inconsistent findings may be related to the species and PM composition in the two studies; welders were exposed to PM with higher levels of metal elements whilst lower metal levels contained in traffic-related air pollution (TRAP). Although the mechanisms underlying alterations in DNA methylation at specific sites associated with PM are less well understood, some evidence indicated that ROS-mediated oxidative stress, central to the downstream effects of PM2.5 exposure, could regulate DNA methylation through inactivation of the methyl donor S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) (Lamadema et al., 2019) or SAM depletion (Kloypan et al., 2015), upregulation of DNMTs and enhanced expression and activity of HDAC (Zhang et al., 2013). In support of the increased risk of lung cancer by PM2.5 exposure, experimental evidence showed that a suppressive effect of repeated PM2.5 exposure on p53 expression via ROS-protein kinase B (Akt)-DNMT3B pathway-mediated promoter hypermethylation (Zhou et al., 2016). Additionally, PM2.5 could induce p16 promoter hypermethylation via a mitochondrial ROS-c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK)-DNMT1 pathway (Soberanes et al., 2012). 2.4.2 Histone modification Histone modification affects the interaction of histone with DNA and effector proteins, resulting in changes in the structure and function of chromatin (Strahl and Allis, 2000). Histone modifications were associated with a pleural of lung diseases. For instance, increased histone H4 acetylation has been proved to be linked with lung inflammation, asthma and also COPD (Ito et al., 2002, 2005). Global modifications on histone H3 and H4 were proposed as potential biomarkers of lung cancer (Song et al., 2012). Ding et al. reported the TRAP-caused dose- and time-effect on histone 3 lysine 9 (H3K9) acetylation in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) and lung tissues of rats, as well as DNA methylation (Ding et al., 2017). Regardless of no significant association in 4 h exposure window, 7-d or prolonged exposure to PM2.5 and PM10 were closely associated with acetylated H3K9 (Ding et al., 2016b). A human study reported elevated H3K27ac patterns in individuals under ambient PM2.5 exposure in Beijing (Liu et al., 2015). However, the Beijing Truck Driver Air Pollution Study observed no association of personal PM2.5 or elemental constituents with histone modifications (including global levels of H3K9 acetylation, H3K9 tri-methylation, H3K27 tri-methylation, H3K36 trimethylation) in blood leukocytes (Zheng et al., 2017). On the other hand, the investigation showed the association between PM10 exposure and lower H3K27/H3K36 tri-methylation levels. The inter-study inconsistencies may due to the differences in sampling times, PM components, and also personal and citywide PM exposures. Some reports also provided evidence of the dysregulated histone acetylation by environmental contaminants that contained PM (Ke et al., 2006; Schnekenburger et al., 2007). An epidemiological study conducted among healthy steel workers with metal-rich PM exposure in Italy, indicated the cumulative exposures to PM-related Ni and as were associated with H3K4 di-methylation and H3K9 acetylation in blood leukocytes (Cantone et al., 2011). Differential histone modification was involved in PM-elicited inflammatory response and oxidative stress (Gilmour et al., 2003), specifically contributing to pulmonary diseases (Bhavsar et al., 2008). Liu et al. obtained genome-wide profiles of H3K27 acetylation in individuals subjected to different levels of PM2.5, and found differential H3K27ac by PM2.5 was related to immune cell activation and inflammatory responses (Liu et al., 2015). Recently, Ji et al. reported that inhaled PM2.5 caused histone modification related to lung dysfunction and inflammation (Ji et al., 2019). Acetylation is reversible and is regulated by two classes of enzymes, including histone acetyltransferases (HATs) to promote acetylation, and histone deacetylase (HDACs) for deacetylation. The balance of HATs and HDACs regulates histone acetylation. Likewise, histone methyltransferases (HMTs) and histone demethylases (HDMs) work together to balance histone methylation. Evidences revealed the contribution of HATs, HDACs and HDMs to the histone modification (acetylation/methylation) induced by airborne PM2.5. Zhou et al. suggested that PM2.5 may exacerbate asthma through the enrichment of H3K9 and H3K14 acetylation in IL-4 gene promoter region of CD4+ T cells, together with increased P300/CBP and declined HDAC1 expressions in mice (Zhou et al., 2019a). Ma et al. confirmed long-term PM2.5 exposure down-regulated histone demethylase Kdm6a expression in pulmonary macrophages, resulting in a increase in H3K4 and H3K9 methylation in promoter regions of IL-6 and IFN-β (Ma et al., 2017). 2.4.3 MicroRNAs (miRs) Accumulating evidence has highlighted the expression profiles of circulating miRs as novel biomarkers for clinical diagnosis of human diseases and for toxicological studies. Equally noteworthy, miRs are key modulators of toxicogenomic response to airborne PM pollution, but the underlying mechanisms remain elusive. Some epidemiology studies have reported up- or down-regulated miRs in processes associated with PM exposure. For instance, increased miR-222 and miR-21 in peripheral blood leukocytes were detected in metal-rich PM-exposed foundry workers (Bollati et al., 2010). Another study pointed out the association of PM with miR-1, −9, −21, −126, −135a, −146a, −155, and −222 in a group of elderly males from the Normative Aging Study (n = 153) (Fossati et al., 2014). In a study of healthy people exposed to TRAP, the researchers observed that short-term PM2.5 exposure (2 h) up-regulated let-7i-5p and miR-98–5p, which may result in the resolution of airway inflammation by reducing the level of IL-13 (Krauskopf et al., 2018). Under high levels of TRAP exposure, asthma-related miR-223–3p was decreased, whilst miR-574–5p was increased. A pilot study suggested the potency of blood miR-194–3p in regulating the toxicological pathways of PM2.5-associated COPD, in view of miR-194–3p positively correlated with lag0–1, forced expiratory volume in 1s (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC) during PM2.5 exposure (Zhou et al., 2018a). A large quantity of experimental evidence has shown global alterations in miRs profiles in the lungs and bronchial epithelium induced by PM (Jardim et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2017). Ning et al. identified 13 differential lung cancer-associated miRs in both serum and lung of PM2.5-exposed mice (Ning et al., 2019). PM2.5 could increase miR-206 in lung tissue of asthmatic mice, with SOD1 as its target, resulting in elevated ROS level, inflammatory response and aggravated asthma symptoms (Wang et al., 2019a). Chronic PM2.5 could induce epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) event through miR-139–5p targeting Notch1 signal pathway (Wang et al., 2020b). Another study also demonstrated miR-802/Rho family GTPase 3 (Rnd3) pathway-mediated the growth and metastasis of lung cancer promoted by PM2.5 (Li et al., 2016). Moreover, miR-486 could relieve PM2.5-induced cell apoptosis and ROS generation by targeting PTEN and FOXO1 in A549 cells (Li et al., 2018a), and miR-194–3p could prevent the bronchial epithelial injury aggravated by PM2.5 through targeting death-associated protein kinase 1 (DAPK1), a regulator of caspase 3 in the apoptotic pathway (Zhou et al., 2018b). The differential derivation and components may partially cause the uncontrolled dysregulation of miRNA caused by PM2.5 exposure (Ning et al., 2019). Notably, in response to PM stimulus, the lung may first go through an adaptation process (e.g., metabolic detoxification, DNA repair, apoptosis activation) via miRs-mediated pathways. However, long-time or prolonged PM2.5 exposure resulted in irreversible miRs alterations. In addition, long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) were also involved in PM2.5-associated respiratory toxicity. PM2.5 activated lncRNA loc146880 through ROS, followed by up-regulating autophagy and promoting malignant behaviors of lung cancer cells (Deng et al., 2017). Collectively, further investigations are in need to fully understand how epigenetic biomarkers influence the health outcome of PM2.5. 2.5 Pulmonary function indexes PM2.5 could penetrate deeply into the lung, irritate the alveolar wall, and eventually impair pulmonary function (Xing et al., 2016). A large quantity of population evidence reflected the correlation of PM2.5 and impaired lung function in children, adolescence and adults. Based on the European Study of Cohorts for Air Pollution Effect (ESCAPE), Gehring et al. analyzed PM2.5 exposure and lung function of children (aged 6–8 y, n = 5921) and found each 5 μg/m3 increase of PM2.5 could reduce FEV1 by 1.77% (95% CI: −3.34%, −0.18%) (Gehring et al., 2013). In Netherlands, Milanzi et al. revealed air pollution was associated with decreased FEV1 growth in adolescence aged 8–16 y and a decrease in FEV1 at age 16, especially in boys (Milanzi et al., 2018), indicating increased airway obstruction under air pollution. Guo et al. also found that remarkably declined lung function in children, adolescents and young people after long-term PM2.5 exposure, but no gender association (Guo et al., 2019). A recent longitudinal cohort study, including 278,065 Taiwan residents (aged ≥ 20 y) also showed a decline of 2.43% in FVC, 2.78% in FEV1, and 3.10% in maximum mid-expiratory flow (MMEF) with each 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 (Guo et al., 2020). Previous studies showed the anti-inflammatory effects of regular physical activity (PA) (Pedersen, 2017). Conversely, PA may attenuate its benefits on lung function in view of PM2.5 intake (Guo et al., 2020). Consistently, a study of 20 healthy men indicated that people with heavily or intensively exercise have a higher risk of respiratory tract inflammation caused by PM2.5 (Chen et al., 2018a). Regardless of the regional air quality, local exposure to traffic-related pollutants, NO2 and PM2.5 on a freeway impaired the lung-function growth in children, and even attained lung function defect at age 18-y old (Gauderman et al., 2007). Additionally, an inverse association between PM2.5 and lung function has been proven in a diesel engine exhaust (DEE) cohort (Zhang et al., 2017). However, a panel study among truck drivers from Beijing, did not find a significant association between PM2.5 and FEV1 or FVC (Baccarelli et al., 2014). It is worth noting that body mass index (BMI) was a confounding factor in analyzing the influence of air pollution on lung function (Xing et al., 2020). Based on Swiss adult population-based SAPALDIA cohort, Schikowski et al. reported the improvement in air quality was associated with an amelioration of lung function among low- and normal-BMI participants, but not overweight or obese participants (Schikowski et al., 2013). A recent cross-sectional study of 6740 children (aged 7–14 y) in China also found the interplays between air pollution and obesity on pulmonary function (Xing et al., 2020). Similarly, a study conducted by Kim et al. in Korean men (aged 51.6 ± 5.7 y) suggested abdominal adiposity could intensify the inverse correlation of air pollution and lung function (Kim et al., 2017). The IQR increase in NO2 level was dramatically associated with a lower of 2.5% in FEV1 (95% CI: −4.6% ~ −0.5%) and 2.9% in FVC (95% CI: −5.1% ~ −0.7%). By studying dust-exposed workers in open-pit Mn mine (280 in total), Huang et al. (Huang et al., 2019) indicated PM2.5-associated pulmonary function damage, as evidenced by lower values of FEV1, MMEF, PEFR, PEFR%, FEF25, FEF75, FEF25%, FEF50%, FEF75%, and FEV1/FVC%. Meanwhile, a higher prevalence of restrictive respiratory dysfunction was detected in comparison to controls (41.4% vs 23.6%, p = 0.016). Likewise, higher prevalence of respiratory diseases was detected in Congolese informal coltan miners, as well as impairment of lung function as indicated by a markedly lower PEFR (347.93 ± 6.88 L/min, whilst 493.23 ± 67.38 L/min for controls) (Leon-Kabamba et al., 2018). The high PM2.5 and increased levels of VOC in mining sites were probably the major contributors, in consideration of an inverse association between PEFR and PM2.5 exposure, between PEFR and VOC exposure. To note, a more strongly association between indoor PM and decreased lung function in children with asthma was manifested as compared with outdoor PM (Isiugo et al., 2019). That may relate to the difference of components in PM2.5 between indoor sources and outdoor origins. For example, Habre et al. suggested that the elemental carbon (EC) in PM2.5 from indoor sources was originated from smoldering combustion, whilst EC in PM2.5 from outdoor origins from internal-combustion engine exhaust soot (Habre et al., 2014). 2.6 Pulmonary Fibrosis Marker Pulmonary fibrosis (PF) is a pathological change caused by inflammation, genetic factors and abnormal immune function, mainly characterized with the proliferation of pulmonary parenchyma and interstitial fibrous tissue, significant thickening of alveolar wall, decrease of pulmonary capillary bed and bronchiole stenosis (Thannickal et al., 2004; Wynn, 2011). Alveolar epithelial injury is the key process of PF. In the context of interactions between genetic susceptibility and harmful environmental factors (Wuyts et al., 2013), repeated injury of alveolar epithelium and the subsequently abnormal repair followed by EMT, lung resident fibroblasts activation, migration and proliferation, inevitably result in the accumulation of extracellular matrix (ECM) and abnormal collagen in lung tissues. A large body of epidemiological investigation and animal researches have suggested PM2.5 pollution acting as a potential initiator of PF (Shull et al., 2021; Cheng et al., 2019; Xu et al., 2019b), and associated with lower lung function, increased risk of acute exacerbation of PF. The aforementioned oxidative stress, inflammatory response and immune cell activation caused after PM2.5 exposure are highly associated with pulmonary fibrosis pathogenesis. Inflammation serves as a relentless driver of fibrogenesis after lung injury, and its persistent stimulus contributes to a vicious cycle with lung injury and fibrotic disorders. A recent in vivo study has unraveled a persistent development of pulmonary fibrosis in post-exposure duration after short-term PM2.5 exposure, probably mediated by oxidative stress-initiated NF-κB/inflammation/EMT pathway (Sun et al., 2020). 2.6.1 Transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β) TGF-β participates in cellular differentiation, proliferation and remodeling processes (Fernandez and Eickelberg, 2012). Accumulating evidence has demonstrated TGF-β is the most potent and ubiquitous profibrogenic cytokine, and involved in lung fibrogenesis (Gauldie et al., 2007). Experimental evidences also showed remarkable increase in TGF-β level in BALF or lung tissues, as well as inflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-1β), contributing to the collagen deposition and fibrogenesis (Xu et al., 2019b; Sun et al., 2020). A recent epidemiology study showed a strong association of TGF-β1 in sputum with PM10 intake from the Saharan desert (Dominguez-Rodriguez et al., 2020). The secretion of IL-1β and inflammatory response in lung is attributed to the increased TGF-β production (dos Santos et al., 2012). TNFα is an inducer of TGF-β (Sullivan et al., 2009), and also, anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-13 is a mediator of fibrogenesis by regulating TGF-β and recruiting leukocytes into lesion site (Lee et al., 2001; Borthwick et al., 2016). Ding et al. indicated long-term PM2.5 exposure led to lung fibrosis through NLRP3 inflammasome activity/IL-1β/TGF-β1 signal pathway (Ding et al., 2019). In addition, TGF-β could stimulate ROS generation; in turn, ROS activate latent TGF-β (Jobling et al., 2006). Numerous studies have shown ROS-mediated oxidative stress was involved in TGF-β’s fibrogenic effects (Sturrock et al., 2006). 2.6.2 Matrix metalloproteases (MMPs) MMPs participate in the tissue remodeling and fibrogenesis process, and play a role in pathogenesis of PM-related pulmonary fibrosis (Pardo et al., 2016). MMP-9, released by inflammatory cells, promotes the migration of inflammatory cells into the airways through extracellular matrix (ECM) destruction, whilst MMP-2 induces collagen deposition disorder and chronic remodeling in lung tissue (Corbel et al., 2002). Moreover, MMPs could activate TGF-β (Dancer et al., 2011). MMP-9 and MMP-2 levels were increased in BALF and lung tissue of pulmonary fibrosis patients (Suga et al., 2000). This phenomenon has also been validated on animal versus cell models. Dose-dependently increased levels of MMP-9, fibronectin, collagen and TGF-β1 protein expression were noticed in PM2.5-exposed human bronchial epithelial cells, and also in lung tissues of PM2.5-exposed mice (Zhao et al., 2019b) and rats (Yang et al., 2018a). Increased change in MMP-9 levels was found in rat serum after wood smoke exposure (Zou et al., 2014). High levels of MMPs in lung tissues were detected in wood smoke- and cigarette smoke-exposed animals (Zou et al., 2014; Zhou et al., 2019b). Besides, experimental evidence on increased expressions and activities of MMPs in alveolar epithelial cells after DEP exposure may partially explain the deleterious effects of PM on lung tissue (Amara et al., 2007; Li et al., 2009). 2.6.3 Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) Studies have preliminarily revealed the correlation of PM2.5 and EMT (Xu et al., 2019a), ultimately contributing to the pathogenesis of PM2.5-elicited lung fibrosis, cancer, COPD. A series of underlying molecular events involved in EMT process has been uncovered. Acute or chronic exposure to PM2.5 altered a series of characteristic EMT-related markers and transcription factors in the epithelia (Xu et al., 2019a). For example, epithelial cadherin (E-cadherin) is crucial for the epithelial integrity (Dongre and Weinberg, 2019), while its down-regulation is an indicator for EMT initiation. A mice study found a dose-dependent decline of E-cadherin in the lung tissue, and increased inflammatory cytokines (IL-2, −6 and −10) upon PM2.5 exposure, which were associated with organic carbon (OC) and free amino acids in PM2.5 (Chuang et al., 2015). Another study inferred that the EMT caused by PM2.5 organic extract was mainly derived from PAH (Chi et al., 2018). In vitro studies revealed the PM2.5-induced phenotype transformation in human bronchial epithelial cells, as evidenced by declined E-cadherin while increased Vimentin (a mesenchymal phenotype marker) (Chi et al., 2018). ROS was linked to multiple inflammatory- and EMT-related signaling pathways, such as MAPK, NF-κB, and hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) (Lamouille et al., 2014). TGF-β could serve as a prototypical cytokine for induction of EMT (Willis and Borok, 2007), meanwhile, MMPs are known for their role in the degradation of epithelial reticular basement membrane for EMT (Polette et al., 2004). MMP-2 and MMP-9 were reported to modulate EMT event in airway epithelial cells caused by cigarette smoke extract (Agraval and Yadav, 2019). Notably, besides the trigger of EMT event, chronic PM2.5 exposure induced the acquisition of obvious cancer stem cells properties in lung tissues/cells (Wei et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019b), which was consistent with the increased lung cancer risk according to the epidemiological investigations. More investigations should perform to combine the necessary endpoints to verify pulmonary EMT and to analyze the specific PM2.5 components contributing to EMT events (Cochard et al., 2020). 2.7 Omics The complex PM's chemical composition limited our understanding of the underlying causal interpretation between PM2.5 and respiratory diseases. Currently, the development and application of high-throughput approaches such as genome, transcriptome, methylome and miRNA sequencing, and proteome, metabolome, are especially useful for providing unbiased information, meet the possibility to reveal the mechanisms of action in support of classical toxicological analyses (Vineis et al., 2013; Chu et al., 2021; Zhao et al., 2021). Recently, Montgomery et al. found that organic components but not the water-soluble extract of PM2.5, elicited a potent, dose-dependent transcriptomic response from the mucociliary epithelium, probably originating from PM2.5-induced the activation of aryl hydrocarbon receptor signaling and IL-1-driven inflammation in the epithelium, resulting in mucus secretion and ciliated cell dysfunction (Montgomery et al., 2020). By using integrative transcriptomic analysis, Longhin et al. evidenced the interaction of oxidative stress, inflammation and DNA damage in PM-exposed BEAS-2B cells (Longhin et al., 2016). Proteomics and metabolomics are powerful tools to screen and identify the critical environmental stresses-related biomarkers. In a mice study to mimic a “real-world” airborne PM2.5 exposure, 32 differentially expressed proteins in total were screened in PM2.5-exposed lung tissue by proteomic technology (Liu et al., 2018). Gene ontology analysis indicated biological processes, like oxidoreductase activity, receptor activity, and protein binding, were responsible for PM2.5-induced lung toxicity. Wei et al. revealed an exposure-response relationship between high-dose PM2.5 exposure and declined unsaturated fatty acids in boilermakers (Wei et al., 2013). Eight circulating metabolites were remarkably correlated with long-term PM2.5 exposure and lung function in a general population (Menni et al., 2015). Among these, the circulating level of α-tocopherol, a biologically active form of the fat-soluble antioxidant vitamin E, manifested the strongest association with both PM2.5 and lung function (FEV1). From a metabolomic perspective, Huang et al. identified 7 PM2.5-associated metabolic biomarkers linked with glycolysis, purine and amino acid metabolism, indicating PM2.5 aggravated COPD via lowering pulmonary antioxidant capacity and energy production (Huang et al., 2018). Similarly, a mass spectrometry-based metabolomics study done by Song et al. also revealed the disturbed purine metabolism, arginine and proline metabolism, GSH metabolism, glycolysis and tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle in PM2.5-exposed BEAS-2B cells (Song et al., 2019). Another in vitro study suggested ceramide accumulation and altered RNA splicing were responsible to PM2.5-induced cytotoxicity of A549 cells (Zhao et al., 2019a). 3 Conclusion Accumulating evidences have demonstrated the adverse respiratory effects of PM2.5, including the induction of lung hyperpermeability, impaired function and structural damage, eventually causing or aggravating some respiratory diseases. Growing evidences have demonstrated the crucial contributions of oxidative stress, inflammatory response, genetic and epigenetic changes on the deleterious respiratory outcome caused by short- or long-term PM2.5 exposure. In the context of updated human, animals and cell studies related to respiratory toxicity caused by PM2.5, we comprehensively summarized some PM2.5-associated biomarkers, which would guide better prevention and control of the damaging effect of PM2.5 on the respiratory system, and help improve our understanding of human complex diseases/traits. Tables 1–3 concisely summarize the evidence for the association between PM exposure and respiratory toxicity-related biomarkers from the population, animal and cell aspects. These biomarkers were primarily involved in eliciting oxidative stress, initiating and aggravating inflammation, genetic or epigenetic alterations, and lung function impairment, and a resultant fibrogenesis and even cancer in the lung. Conversely, Hemmingsen et al. reported 5-h exposure to urban traffic-derived PM2.5 did not increase ROS production, oxidatively damaged DNA or alter gene expressions related to inflammation (IL-8, TNF, MCP-1), oxidative stress or DNA repair (HO-1, OGG1) in PBMCs from elderly overweight people (Hemmingsen et al., 2015). It is worth noting that the currently heterogenous findings likely depend upon the difference in studied PM2.5 (e.g., source, concentrations, components, particle size), exposure mode (acute vs chronic, dose, time of duration), targeted subjects (healthy or diseased). Besides, methodological issues like confounding, publication bias and use of surrogate tissues on biomarker studies are worthy of attention. Biomarkers are reliable tools for the link between clinical respiratory diseases and PM2.5 pollution. The identified biomarkers have potential to unravel the pathways of PM2.5-elicited inflammation, fibrogenesis and carcinogenesis, thereby facilitating a precious public health intervention. Currently, the markers of oxidative stress and inflammation induced by PM2.5 have been fully studied. But the participation of PM2.5 in respiratory diseases is rarely mediated by a single mechanism. There must be multiple markers involved through various modulation ways. The interactions among PM2.5-associated biomarkers need to be further studied, and the functions of each marker in different pathological processes also need to be excavated. Moreover, a suitable integration of multiple biomarkers may be better in the diagnosis and prognosis of PM2.5-caused respiratory diseases. At the same time, more new possible mechanisms of PM2.5-induced disease need to be explored, and more convenient and specific markers need to be discovered. coredata.dc:description: Large amounts of epidemiological evidence have confirmed the atmospheric particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure was positively correlated with the morbidity and mortality of respiratory diseases. Nevertheless, its pathogenesis remains incompletely understood, probably resulting from the activation of oxidative stress, inflammation, altered genetic and epigenetic modifications in the lung upon PM2.5 exposure. Currently, biomarker investigations have been widely used in epidemiological and toxicological studies, which may help in understanding the biologic mechanisms underlying PM2.5-elicited adverse health outcomes. Here, the emerging biomarkers to indicate PM2.5-respiratory system interactions were summarized, primarily related to oxidative stress (ROS, MDA, GSH, etc.), inflammation (Interleukins, FENO, CC16, etc.), DNA damage (8-OHdG, γH2AX, OGG1) and also epigenetic modulation (DNA methylation, histone modification, microRNAs). The identified biomarkers shed light on PM2.5-elicited inflammation, fibrogenesis and carcinogenesis, thus may favor more precise interventions in public health. It is worth noting that some inconsistent findings may possibly relate to the inter-study differentials in the airborne PM2.5 sample, exposure mode and targeted subjects, as well as methodological issues. Further research, particularly by -omics technique to identify novel, specific biomarkers, is warranted to illuminate the causal relationship between PM2.5 pollution and deleterious lung outcomes.
coredata.dc:title: Biomarkers for the adverse effects on respiratory system health associated with atmospheric particulate matter exposure
